reviewText: "Jimmy the Gent" is a very fast moving James Cagney vehicle from early 1934. Cagney was on a wave of successes and Warner Brothers were able to produce very cheaply made box office hits with the magnetic star. In this one, Cagney is on to a racket for bogus heirs. The convolutions of the funny plot are secondary to the machine gun dialogue and endless slang. Cagney apparantly balked at another of these roles so he makes this guy particularly dense, with a great Brooklyn accent and shaved head. As usual, the supporting cast are excellent, lead by a very attractive Bette Davis as his girl and Allen Jenkins as his side kick. Davis spits out her silly lines, matching Cagney's energy. Alice White almost steals the film as Jenkin's dumb girl friend. Michael Curtiz directed this one and the wipes and editing contribute to the frenzy. The film is great fun.The DVD has been issued in the Warner's Archive collection which means it is very expensive, there are no extras and no scene selection. In this case, the theatrical trailer is included and while the DVD has been "re-mastered", it is clean but this is not the same as restored. There are visible tears and white vertical lines etc.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jimmy the Gent ain't no gent. He's more an unscrupulous, conniving so-and-so. Running his crass agency, James Corrigan Personal Contacts, with underhanded zeal, Jimmy Corrigan suffers no money-making opportunity to pass him by; he's got his cowed staff whipped into shape. Jimmy specializes in tracking down lost relatives and missing heirs, and should it turn out that a lost relation or a legal heir can't be found, it only means that Jimmy will cheerfully manufacture one. His only regret is that he allowed his secretary & ex-girlfriend, Joan Martin, to slip away, Joan having signed on with Charles Wallingham (Alan Dinehart), his seemingly above-board and more elegant rival in the genealogy gig. Joan, pretty much the only moral person in this room of reprobates, had had enough of Jimmy's dirty pool shenanigans. Never mind that, of the classy Charles Wallingham, Jimmy growls: "The only difference between him and me is he's got a smoother line!"An old woman expires in a hospital emergency room, the nurse, for identification purposes, rifles thru the deceased's articles of clothing and unearths in the lining a loot of bonds, jewelry, and gold. Wallingham and Corrigan both jump on this, eyes a-gleam with the prospect of hooking up an unwitting heir to his new fortune, for a percentage fee, of course. But what happens when the heir turns out to be a wanted murderer? In the course of all this hearse chasing, Joan Martin learns that her new boss is actually even more corrupt than Jimmy. No lie, the smoother line.1934's JIMMY THE GENT gives us the first of the all-too-few pairings between two of cinema's most forceful and vital actors, James Cagney and Bette Davis. And I prefer JIMMY THE GENT to their later and less energetic picture, THE BRIDE CAME C.O.D. Them folks in the 1940s were fast talkers, but in the '30s the patter was even more rapid-fire. I thoroughly enjoyed Cagney's blistering assault on the English diction. Unable to entirely escape his tough guy gangsta image, Cagney doesn't hesitate to slap his staff around, particularly his skittish and dim-witted chief investigator. At least this time he keeps the mitts off the dames. But you can see why Cagney was so good at playing the heavy.A lot can happen in an hour. JIMMY THE GENT runs at only 67 minutes, and director Michael Curtiz keeps the pace at a breakneck speed. The big treat, naturally, is the interaction between the two leads, with Bette Davis' steely fiber holding up well against Cagney's firecracker performance. She says to him: "You can go down deep and stay under longer and come up dirtier than any man I've ever known." And even more pointedly: "You're the greatest chiseler since Michelangelo." There's an edginess to the banter. After all the scenery chewing, the prop guys probably had little to stow away. JIMMY THE GENT, peopled with skeevy characters engaged in screwy rackets, isn't a gentle comedy. The humor is cynical and even callous. We're presented with a nogoodnik of a "protagonist" who at one point gets a tip about an old bachelor who won't make it thru a medical procedure. When asked by his staff if the guy's dead, Jimmy replies that the tip came from the very doctor performing the surgery. In this movie, Cagney is shady all around, from his ethics to his really effed up haircut. (But you can't help but admire the twisty cleverness of the scheme he hatches for this latest lost heir caper.) As Cagney works to outwit his even more crooked (but terrifically urbane) rival - and as he works to win the girl back - it becomes pretty clear that the audience has become reduced to rooting for the lesser evil. But since it's James Cagney we're pulling for, it goes down more smoothly. Cagney tends to infuse a gritty charm into his incorrigible mugs. Dude's a dynamo.The DVD also comes with the theatrical trailer to JIMMY THE GENT. So, yay.
summary: "Ethics, sweetheart, ethics. I'm just crawling with ethics."

reviewText: We really like James Cagney movies, however, this one is ridiculously stupid with very few laughs in between horrible dialog and a bad Cagney haircut.

reviewText: I bought this movie because Bette Davis is in it and I'm glad I did. It is a good movie and James Cagney just makes it even better. He plays a minor crook that wants to change his ways to impress the person Bette plays. So if you are a Bette fan or a James fan you will want this movie.
